intro: Quercus coccinea var. nigrescens, commonly known as the black栎, is a variant of the scarlet oak characterized by its dark, almost black bark. It is a deciduous tree native to the southeastern United States, typically found in moist, well-drained soils. The leaves are lobed and turn vibrant red in the fall, adding ornamental value to the landscape. It produces small, spiny acorns that are an important food source for wildlife. This species is valued for its aesthetic appeal and ecological contributions in forest ecosystems.
